caption: Humanoid robots with hyper-realistic skin are being developed  by Promobot service robotics manufacturer at the company's branch in the far eastern city of Vladivostok, Russia

candidates.title: Hyper-realistic skin for humanoid robots is being sculpted in Russia
candidates.content:
A laboratory in Russia is experimenting with creating hyper-realistic skin for humanoid robots.
Owned and operated by the company Promobot, the new lab in Vladivostok is using special polymers and 3D-printing to make the coating for a new breed of androids.
Meanwhile, other parts of the company are responsible for building metal frames along with hardware and software to handle movements.
Which begs the question, how long until Russia is full of walking, talking robots indistinguishable from their human inventors?
‘Our key task is to make anthropomorphic robots not just realistic but also attractive, to add a touch of aesthetic,’ Petr Chegodayev, a sculptor and head of the new lab, told Russian media.
‘We have all the necessary conditions for that here in Vladivostok, and I am sure that we will make a qualitative leap in the near future.’
Promobot was founded in 2015 and has become one of the largest manufacturers of autonomous service robots in Russia.
They’re not the only ones producing spookily lifelike ‘bots, either.
Since being unveiled in 2016, Sophia – a humanoid robot – has gone viral. Now the company behind her has a new vision: to mass-produce robots by the end of the year.
Hanson Robotics, based in Hong Kong, said four models, including Sophia, would start rolling out of factories in the first half of 2021, just as researchers predict the pandemic will open new opportunities for the robotics industry.
‘The world of Covid-19 is going to need more and more automation to keep people safe,’ founder and chief executive David Hanson said, standing surrounded by robot heads in his lab.
Hanson believes robotic solutions to the pandemic are not limited to healthcare, but could assist customers in industries such as retail and airlines too.
‘Sophia and Hanson robots are unique by being so human-like,’ he added. ‘That can be so useful during these times where people are terribly lonely and socially isolated.’
Hanson said he aims to sell ‘thousands’ of robots in 2021, both large and small, without providing a specific number.
Social robotics professor Johan Hoorn, whose research has included work with Sophia, said that although the technology is still in relative infancy, the pandemic could accelerate a relationship between humans and robots.

candidates.title: realistic Skin for Humanoids and It's Straight Out of Sci
candidates.content:
Humanoid robots with hyper-realistic skin are being developed by Promobot service robotics manufacturer at the company's branch in the far eastern city of Vladivostok, Russia. Photo: Reuters
The new lab is using polymers and 3D-printing to make the coating for the new batch of robots. Photo: Reuters
Alexandra Chegodaeva, an assistant chief of Promobot analysis and improvement division, works on a head of a humanoid robotic on the firm’s department within the far jap metropolis of Vladivostok. Photo: Reuters
An employee works on a head of a humanoid robot developed by service robotics manufacturer Promobot at their new R&D lab in the far eastern city of Vladivostok, Russia March 15, 2021.This new subdivision includes a 3D modeling center for humanoid robots, a polymer laboratory for developing hyper-realistic artificial skin. Vladivostok has a pretty strong robotics engineering school and the presence of Promobot will give impetus for a strong robotics cluster in the region. Image: Yuri Maltsev/ Reuters
The other branches of the company make metal frames using hardware and software in order to handle movement.Photo: Reuters
candidates.description: Russian Lab Develops Hyper-realistic Skin for Humanoids and It's Straight Out of Sci-fi Movies

result.explanation: This assessment is evidence-based. The news caption accurately reflects the information presented in both sources. Source 1 and Source 2 both report on Promobot's new lab in Vladivostok, Russia, which is focused on developing hyper-realistic skin for humanoid robots using polymers and 3D printing.  Both sources explicitly mention Promobot, Vladivostok, the use of polymers and 3D printing, and the goal of creating hyper-realistic skin. There are no contradictions or inconsistencies between the caption and the provided evidence. The sources are reputable news outlets (metro.co.uk and news18.com), lending further credibility.
supporting_evidence: Source 1: "A laboratory in Russia is experimenting with creating hyper-realistic skin for humanoid robots. Owned and operated by the company Promobot, the new lab in Vladivostok is using special polymers and 3D-printing to make the coating for a new breed of androids."
Source 2: "Humanoid robots with hyper-realistic skin are being developed by Promobot service robotics manufacturer at the company's branch in the far eastern city of Vladivostok, Russia."
